Graphical abstract Transition metal oxides are attractive catalyst alternatives in liquid-phase oxidation reactions due to their lower cost and higher abundance compared with conventional noble metal catalysts. We investigated the catalytic properties of a systematic series of Co3-xFexO4 spinel catalysts synthesized by a hard-templating method, which were applied in the liquid-phase oxidation of styrene, benzyl alcohol and cinnamyl alcohol. O2 and tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) were used as the oxidants in a comparative manner. For alcohol oxidation, TBHP leads to similar or slightly higher selectivity to the corresponding aldehydes compared with O2. For the activation of C=C bonds, TBHP favors the oxidative cleavage pathway, while O2 favors the epoxidation pathway. The comparison of the catalytic performance revealed that the activity of Co3O4 does not benefit from Fe doping using O2 as the oxidant, while the substitution of Fe ≤ 10 % in the spinel structure is beneficial when TBHP is used. This is attributed to the different activation mechanisms of the oxidizing agents, being spin transfer in case of O2 and partial decomposition in case of TBHP. Heterogeneity tests and reusability studies demonstrated the stability of the spinel catalysts. Keywords Liquid-phase oxidation Comparative study Spinel catalyst Co3O4 Synergistic effect Introduction In chemical production, selective oxidation of small molecules with a low degree of functionalization is preferably performed at high temperatures in the gas phase. By comparison, liquid-phase oxidation is used as a mild and more selective alternative for more complex organic molecules in the production of fine chemicals [1]. Selective oxidation reactions in the liquid phase are a class of processes in which substantial potential for improvement is seen [2]. Traditionally, the use of stoichiometric inorganic oxidants produces large amounts of metal-contaminated wastes, e.g., Mn- or Cr-containing wastes [1,3,4]. In the past decades, alternative catalytic processes using O2, H2O2 or tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) as oxidizing agents have been developed [4–7]. The use of Au, Pd and Pt catalysts for liquid-phase oxidation reactions was dominant [8–17], with a focus especially on Au catalysts, sometimes referred to as “gold rush” [18–20]. Although the catalytic properties of these metals remain unchallenged, the high cost and low abundance of the respective noble metals are disadvantageous. Thus, oxides based on first-row transition metals like Co and Fe have also been considered as catalysts for liquid-phase oxidation reactions despite their inferior catalytic properties [7,21,22]. Spinel oxides with the sum formula AB2O4 based on first-row transition metals are among these materials as alternatives to noble metal catalysts [23]. Spinel materials are commonly used in other catalytic applications, such as electrocatalysis [24–30], gas-phase thermal catalysis [29,31,32], and photocatalysis [33]. The structure of spinel oxides enables the introduction of different metals with similar sizes into the materials to enhance the catalytic performance via synergistic effects between those metals. Synergistic effects between Co and Fe have already been observed for selective oxidation reactions both in the gas phase and in the liquid phase [7,34]. For the liquid-phase oxidation of cinnamyl alcohol with TBHP catalyzed by LaCo1-xFexO3, it has been found that small amounts of Fe in the near-surface region are beneficial [7]. Spinel oxides can be synthesized by many different methods from the gas phase, the liquid phase as well as the solid phase [23]. As specific surface area is a decisive factor for the performance of a heterogeneous catalyst, synthesis methods yielding spinels with high surface areas are preferred. Syntheses by hard-templating methods with mesoporous templates yield oxide materials with high specific surface areas and mesoporous structure [24,30,33,35]. In these syntheses, mesoporous ordered silica is often used as the template because of the highly ordered nanostructure and high specific surface area. The template is impregnated by a metal precursor solution. After evaporation of the solvent, the sample is dried and calcined to obtain the respective metal oxides. Finally, the template is removed by washing with NaOH [36]. Substrates for liquid-phase oxidation reactions are often alcohols due to the importance of the produced carbonyl compounds for organic syntheses of fine chemicals [5]. Benzyl alcohol is typically used as a test substrate for oxidation reactions to produce either benzaldehyde or esters by oxidative esterification [37–50]. The use of aromatic compounds such as benzyl alcohol with an OH group in benzylic position as oxidation test substrates offers the advantage of a decreased activation barrier due to the stabilizing mesomeric effect of the aromatic system. The oxidation of cinnamyl alcohol possessing an expanded benzylic system is commonly used as a probe reaction to assess the selective activation of the OH group or the C=C bond [51–58]. Cinnamaldehyde is the product of the alcohol oxidation and is used as a cinnamon flavor and a building block in organic syntheses. Another class of substrates for liquid-phase oxidation reactions are olefins, as these reagents allow to functionalize an unsaturated hydrocarbon feedstock by introducing oxygen. Typical reactants are cyclohexene and styrene among which styrene also offers the benefits of a benzylic activation [59–70]. Epoxides and carbonyl compounds produced by the selective oxidation of olefins are valuable intermediates for further organic transformations. Besides O2, peroxides also can be used as oxidizing agents in the liquid phase, contrary to the gas phase. The use of liquid peroxides reduces the number of phases involved in the reaction and consequently the role of phase boundaries and mass transfer. In many studies, it was found that generally peroxides are more potent oxidizing agents compared with O2, which is attributed to the triplet ground state of O2, hindering the reaction with a singlet-state substrate without prior spin transfer [7]. Among the peroxides H2O2 and TBHP, TBHP is often found to be the more effective oxidant because of its higher stability, preventing the complete decomposition to tert-butanol and O2 [7,71–74]. While O2 needs to be activated by spin transfer to react with a singlet-state substrate, peroxides are mostly found to be activated by partial decomposition to radical reactive oxygen species acting as the actual oxidizing agents [6,7,72,73,75–77]. In the present study, a systematic series of Co3-xFexO4 catalysts was synthesized by a hard-templating method and applied in the selective oxidation of aromatic alcohols and olefins in the liquid phase following a comparative approach. As oxidizing agents, O2 and TBHP were utilized to study the interplay between the Fe amount and the different activation steps of the oxidants. Three representative aromatic compounds, i.e., benzyl alcohol with a hydroxyl group, styrene with a C=C bond, and cinnamyl alcohol with both a hydroxyl group and a C=C bond, were selected as model reactants and investigated in terms of catalyst activity and selectivity towards different products (Scheme 1 ). The heterogeneity of the reactions was verified by means of hot filtration tests and ICP/MS analysis and the reusability of the most active catalyst was also studied. A thorough analysis of the correlation between the Fe amount in the samples and their catalytic performances is presented. Experimental Section Materials Cinnamyl alcohol (98 %), cinnamaldehyde (99 %), trans-cinnamic acid (≥ 99 %), benzyl alcohol (ReagentPlus, ≥ 99 %), benzoic acid (ACS Reagent, ≥ 99.5 %), 2-hydroxy acetophenone (98 %), phenol (≥ 99.5 %), hydroquinone (ReagentPlus, ≥ 99 %), o-dichlorobenzene (99 %) and commercial CoFe2O4 (30 nm, 99 % trace metal basis) were supplied by Sigma-Aldrich. Benzaldehyde (≥ 99 %), benzyl formate (97 %), styrene (99 %), acetophenone (99 %) and (±)-1-Phenyl-1,2-ethanediol (97 %) were obtained from Alfa Aesar. (2R,3R)-3-phenylglycidol (96 %), phenylacetaldehyde (98 %) and TBHP (70 w% in H2O) were supplied by Acros Organics. Styrene Oxide (100 %) was supplied by Merck. Acetonitrile (99.99 %) and toluene (100 %) were obtained from Fisher Chemicals. Dimethylformamide (99.9 %) originated from VWR Chemicals. Oxidation Reactions with TBHP The optimization of the reaction conditions was performed with 10 mg commercial CoFe2O4, 1 mmol styrene (115 μL), varying amounts of TBHP and 3 mL MeCN at 60 °C and atmospheric pressure in air while stirring at 600 rpm for 6 h. Blank experiments were performed accordingly without a catalyst. During the screening of the catalysts, 10 mg catalyst and the substrate (0.15 mmol benzyl alcohol (15.6 μL), 0.15 mmol cinnamyl alcohol (20 mg) or 1 mmol styrene (115 μL)) were dissolved in 3 mL of MeCN. To initiate the reaction, TBHP solution (70 w% in water) was added in a 2:1 molar ratio to the substrate (42 μL for benzyl alcohol and cinnamyl alcohol, 247 μL for styrene). The solution was stirred with 600 rpm at 60 °C and 1 bar for 6 h (benzyl alcohol, cinnamyl alcohol) or 4 h (styrene) in air. GC samples were prepared by filtrating the suspension through a syringe filter (200 nm, PES membrane). Hot filtration tests to investigate possible leaching processes were performed by running the oxidation of styrene for 2 h under the same conditions as in the catalyst screening. A GC sample was drawn as mentioned and the rest of the solutions was filtered in the same way and exposed to the same reaction conditions as before. After additional 2 h, an additional GC sample was taken. To study the reusability of the Co2.91Fe0.09O4 sample, the oxidation of styrene was performed with 5 mmol styrene (573 μL), 10 mmol TBHP (70 w% in water, 1370 μL) in 15 mL MeCN at 60 °C and 1 bar for 4 h using 50 mg material. A GC sample was taken and the rest of the solution exposed to centrifugation (10000 rpm, 5 min). The supernatant solution was removed and the remaining solid washed with 15 mL MeCN. The solvent was removed by the same method and the sample was dried overnight in air. The recovered catalyst was used in two subsequent runs, in which the amounts of reactants and solvent were adjusted to the recovered catalyst amount. Oxidation Reactions with O2 The reaction conditions for the oxidation reactions with O2 were screened with 10 mg commercial CoFe2O4 and 6.1 mmol styrene (700 μL) in 15 mL DMF at 80, 100 or 110 °C and 1 bar. O2 was introduced to the reaction mixture by bubbling through the solution with 20 mL min-1 while stirring at 600 rpm. At 6 h reaction time, a GC sample was taken by filtrating 1.5 mL of the solution through a syringe filter (200 nm, PTFE membrane). For the test performed with an internal standard, 55.8 μL o-dichlorobenzene (0.5 mmol) was added to the reaction mixture. Blank reactions were performed accordingly without a catalyst. The spinel samples were screened with 10 mg catalyst, 6.1 mmol styrene (700 μL), 1.5 mmol benzyl alcohol (156 μL) or 1.5 mmol cinnamyl alcohol (201 mg) in 15 mL DMF with 20 mL min-1 O2 bubbling through the solution at 110 °C (styrene), 120 °C (cinnamyl alcohol) or 140 °C (benzyl alcohol) and 1 bar. GC samples were taken as mentioned above after 3 h (cinnamyl alcohol) or 4 h (benzyl alcohol, styrene). The heterogeneity of the reaction was studied by running the reactions like in the catalyst screening with styrene for 2 h. A GC sample was taken and the solution was filtrated hot through a syringe filter (200 nm, PTFE membrane). The resulting filtrate was stirred under the same conditions as before for an additional 2 h. Catalyst Characterization The CoFe samples for ICP/MS measurements were prepared in an Anton Paar Multiwave PRO by treating 20 mg material with 4 mL of concentrated HNO3 at a maximum pressure of 53.1 bar and between 230 °C and 239 °C maximum temperature. The formed clear solutions were diluted with water to 10 mL. The ICP/MS measurements were measured with a Thermo Scientific iCAP RQ ICP/MS at 1550 W plasma power by measuring 1:1000, 1:10000 and 1:100000 dilutions of the solutions in 2 % HNO3. The liquid hot-filtration samples were prepared in 4 mL of concentrated HNO3 at a maximum pressure of 38.8 bar between 180 °C and 205 °C maximum temperature. The resulting samples were diluted with water to 10 mL. The ICP/MS measurements were measured at 1550 W plasma power by diluting the samples by 1:10 with 2 % HNO3. The XRD pattern of the used catalyst was measured with a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation from 15 – 70° in 0.03° steps. The electron microscopy analyses of the used catalyst were performed with a JEM-2800 by JEOL. The powder was dispersed and drop coated on a Au grid. The beam energy was 200 keV. The effective area of the detector was 200 nm2, yielding a resolution of 0.09 nm in TEM and 0.43 nm in SEM. The images were taken with a Gatan One View camera (4000 × 4000 pixel). The EDS data were obtained with two silicon drift detectors, resulting in a resolution of 123 eV. GC Analysis The analysis of the samples from the styrene and cinnamyl alcohol oxidation was performed with a 7820 A GC system from Agilent Technologies with an Agilent DB-XLB column (30 m × 0.18 mm × 0.18 μm) and an FID detector operating at 300 °C. The injection volume was 0.5 μL in both cases. For the samples from styrene oxidation, the injection occurred at 300 °C with a split ratio of 75:1. The temperature of the oven increased stepwise from 100 to 220 °C. For the samples from cinnamyl alcohol oxidation, the mixture was injected at a temperature of 260 °C and a split ratio of 50:1. The oven temperature increased from 100 °C with 10 °C min-1 to 250 °C. For the oxidation of benzyl alcohol, the reaction mixtures were analyzed using a 7820 A GC as well equipped with an Agilent DB-WAX UI column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) and an FID detector operating at 250 °C. The injected sample amount of 1 μL was introduced into the column with a split ration of 50:1. The column temperature of 130 °C increased with 10 °C min-1 to 230 °C. All analyses were performed two times each. Quantification was achieved by using a normalization method. Therefore, several standard solutions of the substrates, the internal standard and respective oxidation products were prepared and measured. The relative sensitivity factors (RSF) of the substrates were set to 1 arbitrarily and the RSF of the other substances were calculated accordingly. The values and standard deviations of the RSF for the individual substances are given in Table S2. The errors of the individual measurements were calculated by using the Gauss law for propagation of error considering the standard deviations of the GC measurements and of the RSF. Results and Discussion Catalyst Characterization and Reaction Condition Evaluation The series of Co3-xFexO4 spinel catalysts with varying Co and Fe amounts were synthesized via a nanocasting route by using SBA-15 silica as the template (for details on the catalyst synthesis and characterization, see [35]). The XRD patterns of the samples identified the spinel structure of the materials and the absence of other crystalline phases (Figure S1) [35]. N2 physisorption measurements revealed that all materials have very similar specific surface areas around 130 m2 g-1 except for CoFe2O4 with a larger specific surface area of 179 m2 g-1 (Table S1). The analysis of the pore volume shows similar values around 0.4 cm3 g-1 except for Co3O4. The comparison of the Fe/(Co + Fe) ratio in the bulk and in the near-surface region determined by XPS shows enrichment of Fe near the surface for all samples except for CoFe2O4 having a slight surface enrichment of Co. Electron microscopy images revealed that the spinel samples maintain the mesoporosity of the SBA-15 template (Figure S2). For the oxidation reaction using TBHP, acetonitrile (MeCN) was chosen as the solvent because it has been shown in many studies that it is the best solvent for oxidation reactions with peroxides [7,71–74,77]. The reaction temperature was selected to be 60 °C to avoid the loss of TBHP by thermal self-decomposition to tert-butanol and O2, which is known to start at 70 °C [78]. The molar ratio of TBHP to the substrate plays an important role and an excess of TBHP is often used, because partial unproductive decomposition of the oxidant is inevitable [6,7,51,76,79,80]. The oxidation of styrene was performed with TBHP:styrene ratios of 1, 1.5 and 2 using commercial CoFe2O4 as a benchmark catalyst (Fig. 1 a). In all cases, the degrees of conversion with the catalyst are significantly higher than those of the blank reactions, demonstrating the vital role of the catalyst. The main products are styrene oxide from epoxidation and benzaldehyde formed via oxidative cleavage from which benzoic acid results by overoxidation. The selectivities to benzaldehyde are higher for the blank reactions than those of the catalytic reactions due to the higher selectivity to styrene oxide of the CoFe2O4 catalyst. When increasing the TBHP to styrene ratio up to 2:1, conversion increased slightly, suggesting the reaction of styrene with reactive oxygen species from TBHP activation as the rate-determining step. Since the highest degree of conversion was reached with a 2:1 ratio of TBHP to styrene, this ratio was chosen for further tests. A control experiment with TBHP under inert Ar atmosphere led to a similar degree of conversion as found in air, indicating that O2 is not involved in the reaction with TBHP. The oxidation reactions with O2 were performed using dimethylformamide (DMF) as the solvent. It is known that DMF plays the role of a sacrificial reagent besides being a solvent for aerobic oxidation reactions and is often necessary for reactions catalyzed by Co-containing catalysts [60,64,65,81–84]. The oxidation of styrene over commercial CoFe2O4 was performed by bubbling O2 through the solution at ambient pressure and reaction temperatures of 80 to 110 °C (Fig. 1b). The highest conversion of (79.2 ± 0.5) % was reached at 110 °C, following a common Arrhenius-like dependence of the reaction rate. While the selectivity to benzaldehyde and benzoic acid remained roughly the same, the selectivity to styrene oxide increased significantly from (30.9 ± 1.1) % to (49.3 ± 0.3) % with increasing temperature, which is probably caused by a higher activation energy of the epoxidation pathway compared with the oxidative cleavage. Other products formed only in minor amounts were phenylacetaldehyde and 2-hydroxy acetophenone. The addition of o-dichlorobenzene to the reaction mixture as an internal standard showed that the mass balance of styrene was only fulfilled to 83 %. Possible reasons are the evaporation of styrene due to its high volatility, the formation of gaseous products as well as the self-polymerization of styrene starting at > 100 °C [85]. Due to the increased degree of conversion and epoxidation selectivity, 110 °C was chosen as the reaction temperature for the oxidation of styrene with O2 in DMF. The blank reaction under the same conditions resulted in a degree of conversion of (26.9 ± 0.5) %, emphasizing the necessity of a catalyst. Styrene Oxidation The oxidation of styrene over the mesoporous CoFe spinel catalysts was investigated with both oxidizing agents using the evaluated reaction conditions. While the selectivities with the different catalysts and the same oxidizing agent were very similar, there is a substantial difference in selectivities between the two oxidizing agents (Table 1 ). For the reaction with TBHP, benzaldehyde was the main product with 63 – 65 % selectivity, whereas when using O2 as the oxidant, styrene oxide was formed primarily with 34 – 52 % selectivity. The higher selectivity towards epoxidation in case of O2 can be explained either by the different nature of the oxidizing agent or by the higher reaction temperature [86]. Additionally, more benzoic acid from overoxidation of benzaldehyde was formed when oxidizing with O2, which can also be explained by the higher reaction temperature combined with the different nature of the oxidant. To investigate whether benzaldehyde is formed via styrene oxide as the intermediate species, the oxidation of styrene oxide was performed under the same conditions as styrene oxidation, with both TBHP and O2. No conversion of styrene oxide was observed in both cases even after 10 h. Thus, benzaldehyde is formed via a different pathway and styrene oxide is the end of its reaction branch. This result is consistent with findings published earlier [60,64], while other groups proposed a consecutive reaction of styrene oxide to benzaldehyde [66,69,87,88]. The highest degree of conversion with TBHP was obtained with Co2.91Fe0.09O4 (2.8 % Fe in the bulk), while the highest degree of conversion was reached with Co3O4 in the aerobic oxidation of styrene (for more details on the evolution of conversion over the different samples, see section 3.4). For these two most active catalysts, hydroquinone was added to the reaction mixture as a radical scavenger (10 mol% relative to styrene) to verify whether the reaction proceeds via a radical mechanism as found earlier [7,65,89]. For the reaction with TBHP, the degree of conversion decreased from 53 % to 25 % by adding hydroquinone, indicating a radical reaction. For the aerobic oxidation of styrene, the addition of hydroquinone suppressed the conversion of styrene completely, resulting in the same conclusion. A kinetic study of styrene oxidation with TBHP over the best performing catalyst Co2.91Fe0.09O4 showed a high reaction rate at the beginning of the reaction (Fig. 2 a). Afterwards, the degree of conversion increased at a reduced rate. The selectivity towards benzaldehyde decreased over time, while the styrene oxide selectivity continuously increased, reflecting the competing reaction pathways between the oxidative cleavage and the epoxidation. Furthermore, the decrease of benzaldehyde is also partly due to the formation of benzoic acid by overoxidation after 2.5 h. For styrene oxidation with O2 over Co3O4 (Fig. 2b), the degree of conversion started to increase after a pronounced induction period of roughly 0.5 h, which has also been found earlier for aerobic styrene oxidation over Co-containing catalysts [65]. As the reaction proceeds via a radical mechanism, a certain amount of radical chain propagators must form during the induction period and subsequently initiates the reaction. The overoxidation of the formed benzaldehyde to benzoic acid sets on earlier compared with TBHP, which is reflected by a pronounced decrease in benzaldehyde selectivity after 0.5 h and the corresponding increase in selectivity towards benzoic acid. The styrene oxide selectivity remained roughly the same up to 2.5 h but declined afterwards, coupled with a slight increase in benzaldehyde selectivity. Catalyst Stability and Reusability In liquid-phase reactions catalyzed by heterogeneous catalysts, leaching of the active component into the reaction solution is often an issue, leading to catalyst deactivation or separation problems after the reaction [90]. To investigate the heterogeneous nature of the spinel catalysts during styrene oxidation with TBHP and O2, hot filtration tests were performed (Fig. 3 ). For both reactions, the catalyst was filtered off after 2 h reaction time and the filtrate was exposed to the same conditions for an additional 2 h. In case of TBHP as the oxidant, the degree of conversion did not increase significantly after the catalyst was filtered off and was far below the conversion reached after 4 h with a catalyst. Using O2 as the oxidant, the degree of conversion did increase in a significant amount after the catalyst was filtered off, however not as much as the reaction with the catalyst after 4 h. ICP/MS measurements of the filtrated solutions showed that the amounts of Co and Fe in the liquid were below the detection limit, confirming that the oxidation reactions proceed heterogeneously. The increase in conversion without a catalyst especially in the case of O2 can be explained by the radical nature of the reaction, maintaining the chain propagation to some extent even in the absence of a catalyst. The stability of the catalysts was further investigated by applying the Co2.91Fe0.09O4 sample in a reusability study (Fig. 4 ). The degree of conversion slightly decreased from the first to the second use but remained stable afterwards. XRD investigations after the first use showed that the spinel structure did not change and no other crystalline phases were present (Figure S3). Electron microscopy images showed that the crystallinity and the mesostructure of the sample were maintained (Figures S4a and b). EDS elemental mapping indicated no segregation of single Co or Fe oxides on a microscopic level (Figure S4c - f). Based on these results, it can be concluded that the spinel catalyst is rather stable and relatively reusable. Oxidation of Alcohols and Synergistic Effects To expand the scope of the reactants beyond styrene, benzyl alcohol and cinnamyl alcohol were also oxidized over the CoFe spinel catalysts using TBHP and O2 as oxidizing agents (Table 2 ). When using TBHP as the oxidant, the highest degrees of conversion were obtained with the Co2.91Fe0.09O4 and Co2.95Fe0.05O4 samples for the oxidation of benzyl alcohol and cinnamyl alcohol, respectively. Contrary to the reactions with TBHP, the highest degree of conversion using O2 as oxidant was achieved with Co3O4 for both alcohols. In terms of selectivity, both oxidants led to rather similar selectivities of > 80 % to benzaldehyde for benzyl alcohol oxidation, with benzoic acid being the only byproduct formed by overoxidation. In the case of the cinnamyl alcohol oxidation, the selectivity towards cinnamaldehyde is higher with TBHP as the oxidant reaching more than 60 % compared with O2. Simultaneously, the selectivity for the epoxide 3-phenylglycidol is higher using O2 as the oxidant, which is consistent with the higher selectivity towards styrene oxide in the styrene oxidation with O2 (Table 1). To conclude, TBHP leads to similar or slightly higher aldehyde selectivities compared with O2. For the activation of a C=C bond, TBHP favors the oxidative cleavage pathway, while O2 results in a higher epoxidation selectivity. Notably, Co3O4 containing no Fe shows the highest activity for the oxidation of all three substrates utilizing O2 as the oxidizing agent. The degree of conversion of the different substrates exhibits a similar trend regarding the amount of Fe in the near-surface region of the materials (Figs. 5 a, b and c). From the most active Co3O4 without Fe, the degree of conversion decreases rapidly as soon as small amounts of Fe are present in the materials. Up to the catalyst with the highest Fe amount (CoFe2O4), a tendency for a gradual increase in conversion is present, which can be explained by the higher specific surface area of this material. Contrary to the oxidation with O2, the degree of conversion with TBHP as the oxidant first increases and reaches a maximum when increasing the Fe content up to an amount of below 10 % in the near-surface region (Figs. 5d, e and f). Higher Fe amounts lead to decreased catalytic performances. The exceptionally high conversion over CoFe2O4 is likely due to the higher specific surface area of this material. The analysis of a correlation between the pore volume and the catalytic properties of the CoFe catalysts revealed no link between those parameters, excluding the pore volume as an influence factor (Figure S5). The observation that small amounts of Fe in Co-containing oxide catalysts are beneficial for oxidation reactions with TBHP is consistent with our earlier findings in the oxidation of cinnamyl alcohol over LaCo1-xFexO3 [7]. It seems that the doping of Fe into a Co3O4 catalyst enhances the partial decomposition of TBHP to reactive oxygen radicals, which has been found to be the first step in the oxidation reaction to activate the oxidant. On the contrary, O2 needs to be activated by a spin transfer to a singlet state and thus the reaction requires a different activation mechanism of the oxidant. The superior catalytic properties of Co as the active metal compared with other metals such as Fe have been found in earlier studies [65,81,86,91]. Our previous results for the gas-phase aerobic oxidation of isopropanol over Co3O4 presented 5-fold-coordinated octahedral surface Co3+ atoms as the active sites [31]. Based on these results, it can be concluded that Fe3+-substitution does not enhance the catalytic performance of Co3O4 using O2 as the oxidizing agent and a Co3+-containing ensemble may also be the active site in the liquid phase. Conclusions In this comparative study, a series of Co3-xFexO4 spinel catalysts synthesized by a hard-templating method was applied in the selective oxidation of styrene, benzyl alcohol and cinnamyl alcohol with both TBHP and O2 in the liquid phase. These three compounds enabled us to systematically investigate and compare the activation of the hydroxyl group and the C=C bond. The reaction conditions of the oxidation reactions with TBHP and O2 were optimized by oxidizing styrene and the evaluated conditions were chosen for further oxidation of the aromatic alcohols. In terms of the different oxidation products, O2 as the oxidant favors the epoxidation pathway in case of styrene and cinnamyl alcohol, highlighting the different oxidation pathways between the two oxidants. The heterogeneity of the catalyzed reactions was confirmed by hot filtration tests and ICP/MS measurements of the filtrated solutions. Co2.91Fe0.09O4 was demonstrated to be reusable for the oxidation of styrene with TBHP and the stability of the material was verified by means of XRD, TEM, SEM and EDS measurements. In terms of the catalytic performance of the catalysts, a detailed analysis of the dependence of the degree of conversion on the near-surface Fe/(Co + Fe) ratios showed that Fe substitution below 10 % is beneficial for oxidation reactions with TBHP, while no beneficial synergistic effect by introducing Fe to Co3O4 catalyst is identified using O2 as the oxidant. The difference between the two oxidizing agents is rationalized by their different activation mechanisms, namely partial decomposition of the peroxide and spin transfer of O2. coredata.dc:description: Transition metal oxides are attractive catalyst alternatives in liquid-phase oxidation reactions due to their lower cost and higher abundance compared with conventional noble metal catalysts. We investigated the catalytic properties of a systematic series of Co3-xFexO4 spinel catalysts synthesized by a hard-templating method, which were applied in the liquid-phase oxidation of styrene, benzyl alcohol and cinnamyl alcohol. O2 and tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) were used as the oxidants in a comparative manner. For alcohol oxidation, TBHP leads to similar or slightly higher selectivity to the corresponding aldehydes compared with O2. For the activation of C=C bonds, TBHP favors the oxidative cleavage pathway, while O2 favors the epoxidation pathway. The comparison of the catalytic performance revealed that the activity of Co3O4 does not benefit from Fe doping using O2 as the oxidant, while the substitution of Fe ≤ 10 % in the spinel structure is beneficial when TBHP is used. This is attributed to the different activation mechanisms of the oxidizing agents, being spin transfer in case of O2 and partial decomposition in case of TBHP. Heterogeneity tests and reusability studies demonstrated the stability of the spinel catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Investigation of Synergistic Effects between Co and Fe in Co3-xFexO4 Spinel Catalysts for the Liquid-Phase Oxidation of Aromatic Alcohols and Styrene
